0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Merck has decided to stop production of MERUVAX(R) II (Rubella Virus Vaccine Live) and will continue to manufacture only the combination vaccine.
  • Rubella; Prophylaxis: 0.5 mL SUBQ x 1 dose

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Merck has decided to stop production of MERUVAX(R) II (Rubella Virus Vaccine Live) and will continue to manufacture only the combination vaccine.
  • safety and effectiveness in infants below the age of 12 mo have not been established
  • Rubella; Prophylaxis: (12 mo and older) 0.5 mL SUBQ x 1 dose

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Merck has decided to stop production of MERUVAX(R) II (Rubella Virus Vaccine Live) and will continue to manufacture only the combination vaccine [1].
  • Rubella; Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Active febrile infection
  • Acute febrile illness (eg, febrile respiratory illness)
  • Active, untreated tuberculosis
  • Blood dyscrasias, leukemia, lymphomas, bone marrow malignancy
  • Family history of congenital or hereditary immunodeficiency
  • History of anaphylactic reactions to topical or systemic neomycin
  • Hypersensitivity to the vaccine components, including gelatin
  • Primary or acquired immunodeficiency including immunocompromised HIV
  • Immunosuppressive therapy (eg, corticosteroids, radiation, alkylating agents, antimetabolites)
  • Pregnancy
  • Pregnancy should be avoided for 28 days postvaccination based on Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommendations (Anon, 2001); pregnancy should be avoided for 3 months postvaccination based on manufacturer recommendations

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Defer vaccination at least 3 months following blood or plasma transfusions and administration of immune globulin, with the exception of postpartum vaccination of women who have received Rho(D) immune globulin and are susceptible to rubella; vaccination should NOT be delayed
  • Extremely remote risk for transmission of viral diseases
  • Fever may occur following vaccination
  • History of contact dermatitis to neomycin
  • HIV-infected patients
  • Special care should be taken to ensure that the injection does not enter a blood vessel
  • Temporary depression of tuberculin skin test sensitivity
  • Current thrombocytopenia

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breast-feeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

2.mono:

  • Varicella-Zoster Immune Globulin (probable)

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site, Injection site pain, Rash
  • Immunologic:Lymphadenopathy
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia, Women (12-26%), Arthritis, Women (12-26%), Myalgia, Women (12-26%)
  • Respiratory:Common cold
  • Other:Fever
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Stevens-Johnson syndrome
  • Hematologic:Thrombocytopenia
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Neurologic:Encephalitis, Guillain-Barr syndrome, Association with vaccine unlikely, Polyneuritis, Polyneuropathy
  • Ophthalmic:Optic neuritis

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Following subcutaneous injection, rubella virus vaccine live produces a modified, noncommunicable rubella infection and provides active immunity to rubella .

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    for SubQ use only; do not inject IV
  • Subcutaneous
    • do not give concurrently with immune globulin
    • mix with supplied diluent, give SubQ in outer aspect of upper arm
    • do not give less than one month before or after administration of other live virus vaccines

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Counsel female patients to use reliable contraception to avoid pregnancy for at least 3 months post-vaccination.
  • This vaccination should be deferred at least 3 months following blood or plasma transfusions and administration of immune globulin.
  • This product contains human albumin. Despite screening and testing, human plasma products carry a risk of transmitting infectious agents. Risks and benefits should be discussed with patient by healthcare professional.
  • This drug may cause arthralgia, arthritis, or myalgia in female patients. Drug may also cause lymphadenopathy or symptoms of the common cold.
  • Advise patient to report fever or signs/symptoms of thrombocytopenia or Stevens-Johnson syndrome (flu-like symptoms, spreading red rash, or skin/mucous membrane blistering).
  • Patient should also report signs/symptoms of optic neuritis, polyneuritis, or polyneuropathy.
  • Tell patient to avoid other vaccines one month before or one month after having this vaccine, unless approved by healthcare professional.
